review.title: Encoding Temporal Markov Dynamics in Graph for Time Series Visualization
review.abstract: Time series is attracting more attention across statistics, machine learning and pattern recognition as it appears widely in both industry and academia, but few advances has been achieved in effective time series visualization due to its temporal dimensionality and complex dynamics. Inspired by recent effort on using network metrics to characterize time series for classification, we present an approach to visualize time series as complex networks based on first order Markov process and temporal ordering. Different to classical bar charts, line plots and other statistics based graph, our approach delivers more intuitive visualization that better preserves both the temporal dependency and frequency structures. It provides a natural inverse operation to map the graph back to time series, making it possible to use graph statistics to characterize time series for better visual exploration and statistical analysis. Our experimental results suggest the effectiveness on various tasks such as system identification, classification and anomaly detection on both synthetic and the real time series data.

metadata.title: Encoding Temporal Markov Dynamics in Graph for Time Series Visualization

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The time of the data series is a challenge in both industry and science. Apart from the perceptual signals that we can easily understand, such as audio, video, and natural language, most other time series that are generated are mechanical signals. Therefore, understanding temporal patterns is key to gaining insight and insight. Our ability to store data, however, far exceeds the speed at which we can understand them. Scientists and domain experts expect to discover patterns to help further understand these mechanical signals in various tasks such as classification and anomalous recognition. Learning the (long) temporal correlations that are often embedded in time series remains a major challenge. The visualization of time series provides a new perspective to explore these complex dynamics more intuitively. Many visualization methods have been introduced to address time series tasks. The time frame graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph graph-h is a challenge.

sections.heading: 2 DATA TRANSFORMATION AND QUANTITATIVE ENCODING
sections.text: Time and frequency correlations are important dependencies embedded in time series data. To build a comprehensive but intuitive visualization, the features extracted from the designed data transformation frame should be able to represent the dynamics both in time and frequency, while there is a reverse operation to map the information back to raw time series. In this section we will introduce how to encode the dynamic frequency information in the time order step by step (Figure 1).

sections.heading: 2.1 Quantization and Markov Matrix
sections.text: This framework is similar to [3] for the coding of dynamic transition statistics. We develop this idea by sequentially representing the Markov transition probabilities Q = Q in the temporal dimension in order to obtain information in the temporal dimension. The first step is to quantify time series in order to obtain the first order of the Markov matrix.Given a time series X = {x1, x2, · · ·, xn}, we must quantify their values in Q containers. − Quantile is the most common way to achieve a discredited dictionary. sections.heading: 2.2 Markov Transition Field and Network Graph
sections.text: The Markov matrix, which contains the Markov dynamics, rejects the conditional relationship between the distribution of X and the temporal dependence on the time steps ti. The Markov transition field (MTF) expands the Markov matrix by aligning every probability along the temporal order. M = M11 M12 · · M1n M21 M22 · · · · M2n........ Mn1 Mn2 · · · Mnn = wi j | x1% qi, x1% q j | wi | x1% qi, xn% qi, x2% qi, x1% q · q · qi, x2% corresponds to the temporal probability.

sections.heading: 2.3 Dimension Reduction
sections.text: To make the matrix size manageable for more efficient calculation and visualization, two common dimension reduction techniques can be applied before or after MTF encoding: • Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) assumes that the time series of n dimensions are reduced to w dimensions, the data is split into w frames of equal size. PAA is a special case of the moving average model when the skip size corresponds to the length of the sliding window. • Blur to MTF is achieved by averaging the pixels in each non-overlapping m x m patch with a linear combination of core functions. • Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) requires that the time series of n dimensions is reduced to w dimensions, and the data is divided into w frames of equal size.

sections.heading: 3 VISUAL ENCODING AND INVERSE MAPPING
sections.text: For general inspection, the graph G = (V, E) generated from the MTF has a direct mapping from the vertex V to the time index i in the original time series. It is easy to encode the time index {1,2,..., n} as the color of the vertices. Along the time axis, we select PageRank weights as the vertex and Markov matrix weight as the edge color to observe when (to which vertex) the large flow of information / citations occurs. Modularity is an important pattern in network analysis to identify the specific local structures. To verify the modules and unique patterns, we also determine the modularity designation and cluster coefficient [2, 12] for each vertex and assign them to the original time series.

sections.heading: 4 EXPERIMENTS AND ANALYSIS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 System Identification
sections.text: In order to emphasize the potential of the encoding described above, we first apply it to two time series belonging to different dynamic systems (Figure 1). The first time series is the variable of the chaotic Lorenz equations dt = σ (− x + y), which are embedded in a three-dimensional space with coordinates. The trajectory revolves around two unstable fixed points, which then escape into the orbit of the other fixed points. This behavior is evident in the variable X plane, which is embedded in a three-dimensional space with coordinates.

sections.heading: 4.2 Anomaly Detection
sections.text: We are testing our visualization approach to three typical composite functions [17] with different types of outliers to see if we can identify the outliers using the diagram and network statistics (12x); the notch function is defined by (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), (x), x (x, x, x, x, x, x, x, x, (x), (x), (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), x, (x), x, (x), (x), (x), x, (x), (x), (x, (x), x, (x), (x), (x, x), (x, (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), (x, x, x, (x), x, (x), (x), (x, (x), x, x, (x), (x), (x), (x, x, x, (x), (x, x), (x), (x), (x), (x (x, x), (x), (x), (x), (x, (x), (x, (x), (x, (x, x), (x), (x), (x), (x, (x, (x), (x, (x), (x, (x), (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), (x, (x), (x), (x, (

sections.heading: 4.3 Classification
sections.text: Our final experiment consists in identifying the class labels on three real-time series datasets: ECG, wafer and gun point [18]. The ECG dataset is a time series of measurements taken by an electrode during a heartbeat. Cardiologists commented on the data and each dataset is assigned a label for normal or abnormal. The Gun Point dataset contains two-dimensional time series that are taken from the video of two actors aiming either at a weapon or simply at a target. Both dimensions correspond to the X and Y coordinates of the actors on the right. For convenience, we only look at the Y axes. The wafer dataset is recorded by a vacuum chamber sensor during the etching process of silicon wafers for semiconductor manufacturing with normal or abnormal structures.

sections.heading: 4.4 Network Statistics and Summary
sections.text: Our encoding network graph not only supports the purpose of visualizing time series, it also bridges visual analysis, network dynamics, and analysis of time series with a natural inverse map from network graph to original time series. Networks can be analyzed by exploring an extensive set of statistical properties of the associated time series with an active visual understanding, while simultaneously visualizing and understanding various dynamic regimes in time series by exploring an extensive set of topological statistics in the associated network domain. Table 2 summarizes some common network statistics for all of our experimental datasets [1]. On the ECG, wafers and gun point datasets capture the average across all samples with specific labels.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we present a novel visualization framework for translating time series into the network graph. Built using the Markov matrix variant called the Markov transition field, the graph is capable of encoding both temporal order and statistical dynamics. Our encoding map also features a natural inversion that allows visual exploration of the interesting patterns in the generated graph and inverse mapping to the original data. Experiments with benchmark and real-time row data demonstrate the effectiveness of our visualization framework in three tasks: system identification, classification and anomaly detection. The inverse mapping is done one-on-one, thereby establishing a link between pattern recognition in the network graph and time series data analysis. Furthermore, our work bridges the gap between visual analysis on time series and network analysis, as the generated network graph can be analyzed to support a comprehensive set of statistical properties associated with further interactive understanding of the network structure.
